description: From Middle English swiven, from Old English swīfan (“to move, sweep, wend, revolve”), from Proto-Germanic *swībaną (“to wipe, sweep”), from Proto-Indo-European *weyp- (“to twist, wind around, swing, sweep, bend”). Cognate with Old Frisian swīva, swīfa (“to waver”), Old Norse svīfa (“to drift, ramble, rove”), Norwegian Nynorsk sviva (“to rotate, wander”). Related to Old English swift (“swift”), Middle English swyvel (“swivel”).

verbs.description: swive (third-person singular simple present swives, present participle swiving, simple past and past participle swived)

examples: Synonyms: occupy, sard, jape, roger, fuck; see also Thesaurus:copulate with

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive, dialectal) To cut a crop in a sweeping or rambling manner, hence to reap; cut for harvest.
examples: Synonyms: crop, gather, glean, harvest, mow
